data.title: Facebook agrees to $52 million settlement to workers who were content moderators
data.text: Facebook agreed to compensate $52 million to its content moderators who developed PTSD and other mental health issues on the job.

data.title: Facebook Will Pay Out $52 Million After Failing To Protect Moderators From Dangers Of Extreme Content
data.text: Thousands of former and current content moderators will receive compensation after suffering with mental health issues, including PTSD.

data.title: It’s Not Too Late to Buy Facebook Stock
data.text:
FB stock is rated as a buy, after recovery from the mid-March sell-off and shrugging off concerns the coronavirus would gut ad revenue.
The post It’s Not Too Late to Buy Facebook Stock appeared first on InvestorPlace.

data.title: Facebook Removed 9.6M Posts For Hate Speech In Q1, Warns Of Coronavirus Impact On Content Moderation
data.text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) in its Community Standards Enforcement Report on Tuesday said it removed 9.6 million posts in the first three months of 2020 for hate speech.

data.title: Facebook to pay $52m to moderators who saw disturbing images
data.text: Facebook has agreed to pay $52m (£42m) to thousands of content moderators who had to view disturbing images of rape, suicide and murder posted on the social network.

data.title: The Market On Pulling Guidance: This Is The Way
data.text: The Market On Pulling Guidance: This Is The Way

data.title: Facebook To Pay $52M In Settlement With Content Moderators Who Suffered Mental Injuries
data.text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) has agreed to settle a class action filed on behalf of content moderators who said their mental health suffered on the job, the law firms involved in the case announced Tuesday.

data.title: Facebook to pay content moderators $52M in class action settlement
data.text: Facebook will pay content moderators who are tasked with repeatedly monitoring graphic material on its platform $52 million as part of a class-action lawsuit settlement. The social media company was sued in 2018 by third-party contractors who argued Facebook failed to adequately protect them against psychological injuries than can result from continued exposure to disturbing.
